articles.name: Web Access - How to Approve or Deny Access Requests
articles.title: Web Access - How to Approve or Deny Access Requests
articles.body:
You may receive an access request from a user trying to view a secure email you sent. This request may be because the email has been forwarded to them, or they have tried to view it using an alternative email address.

You will receive an email notification informing you that access has been requested. The user's details will be in the email allowing you to decide whether or not access should be granted.

To grant access, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to the Administration Panel.

  2. Select Sent Packages on the side menu.

  3. Select the With Pending Requests tab.

  4. Select the recipient name under The following users have requested access to this package.
  5. You can then choose to Approve Request or Deny Request.
  6. Ensure you select Save when approving requests or amending permissions.

articles.name: Additional Password or PIN Protected Emails
articles.title: Additional Password or PIN Protected Emails
articles.body:
After opening a secure email, you may be asked for an additional password or a PIN after signing in with your ID and password. 

This email is referencing an additional password created by the sender and should have been sent to you separately.

If you have not received an additional password or the password is not working, please contact the original sender of the secure email, who will be able to confirm the correct additional password for you.

articles.name: "Unexpected Error" "The package is unavailable at the moment" Error Message
articles.title: "Unexpected Error" "The package is unavailable at the moment" Error Message
articles.body:
You may see an error similar to the image below when trying to access an email:

There are two possible causes for this error.

Opening an Older Email

If you open an old email, the link in the email will have been severed due to inactivity. If this is the case, please forward the email from your inbox to open@reader.egress.com to receive a new link. This action will send you an automated email containing a new link to access the email.

Opening a New Email

If the email is very recent, you will need to contact the sender, as it may not have been uploaded fully at their end, and they may need to resend the email. Sometimes, following the instructions above can also resolve this issue.

articles.name: Access to Message Revoked
articles.title: Access to Message Revoked
articles.body:
If you see the message below when trying to access an email, then the sender has revoked access to the package or removed your email address from the email access list.

If you need access, you will need to contact the sender of the email. Support does not have access to do this.

articles.name: Access to Message Denied Because It Has Expired
articles.title: Access to Message Denied Because It Has Expired
articles.body:
You may see the error below when attempting to open a secure email:

This error occurs when the sender has placed time restrictions on the email, and you are trying to access it before or after those restrictions.

To access this email, the message's author must alter the time and date restrictions. Once this has been done, you can view the email.

articles.name: “Unable To Access Package” “Package Is Unknown to Server” Error Messages
articles.title: “Unable To Access Package” “Package Is Unknown to Server” Error Messages
articles.body:
You may encounter an error message that states there was a problem accessing the package because the package is unknown to the server:

This error usually occurs when the email fails to upload correctly on the sender's side. If you are the recipient, please advise them of the following causes and resolutions.

This error could have been caused by:

  • The user changes their password but fails to log out and back in.
  • Connectivity issues when sending the email cause the email to fail to upload and become stuck in the outbox.

This issue should be resolved if the sender logs out and returns to their account. Alternatively, the recipient can try forwarding the secure email to open@reader.egress.com, which will send a new link to try to access the email.

articles.name: Client "Working Offline", "Cannot connect to remote server", "SSL/TLS" Errors
articles.title: Client "Working Offline", "Cannot connect to remote server", "SSL/TLS" Errors
articles.body:
This article will help you resolve the "Working Offline," "SSL/TLS," or "Cannot connect to remote server" errors. These errors are usually caused by a proxy or firewall blocking the URLs that the Microsoft Outlook client needs to connect to to verify our SSL certificates' validity.

You may also need to allow these addresses through any firewalls or proxies where packet inspecting occurs. Packet inspection can impact the connectivity and performance of the Microsoft Outlook client service.

The issue can be resolved by whitelisting the following URLs:

  • http://crl3.digicert.com/DigiCertHighAssuranceEVRootCA.crl
  • http://cdp.geotrust.com/GeoTrustEVRSACA2018.crl
  • crl.usertrust.com
  • ocsp.usertrust.com
  • ocsp.sectigo.com
  • switch.egress.com
  • http://gc.egress.com
  • lencr.org

Depending on your Protect location, you will also need to allowlist your region:

  1. Us1.esi.egress.com
  2. Au.esi.egress.com
  3. Eu1.esi.egress.com

Ports 80 and 443 should also be open to allow access to switch.egress.com.

Prevent

If you are a Prevent customer, add the following exception:

  • *.intelligence.egress.com
Note:If your proxy, firewall, or AV doesn't allow wildcards, whitelist <region>.intelligence.egress.com based on your Prevent Region. The regions are the UK, EU, and US.

Large File Transfer

Large file transfers are uploaded to Amazon S3 (UK) by default. For the right URLs to allowlist according to the location of your Amazon instance, read Amazon's Service Endpoints Support page.

articles.name: "CP-SVC: Failure calling CP service" Error Message
articles.title: "CP-SVC: Failure calling CP service" Error Message
articles.body:
This error can occur when a firewall or proxy causes an issue connecting to the ADFS or single sign-on (SSO) server.

If you're using ADFS and a user's principal name (UPN) has been changed recently, they may receive an ADFS error when signing into the client, such as CP-SVC: Failure calling CP service, or the web portal, such as Email claim not found. 

The Microsoft Outlook client logs will show if an email claim is not being passed or if there's a connectivity issue. 

Cause

The Microsoft Outlook client is having trouble connecting to the ADFS or SSO server, which is preventing our add-in from claiming a refresh token from the server.

If you are setting up ADFS integration for the first time, you may get this error with test accounts where a mailbox has not been linked to the account. 

Resolution

This issue can be resolved by one of the following items: 

  • Troubleshooting a connectivity issue between the add-in and the SSO server by checking firewalls or proxy servers for exceptions being present
  • Rebooting the AD FS server clears the LSA user name to the SID translation cache
  • Change the LsaLookupCacheMaxSize registry key by following this Microsoft Guide

articles.name: Receiving a winmail.dat/win.dat File in a Secure Email
articles.title: Receiving a winmail.dat/win.dat File in a Secure Email
articles.body:
If you or your recipients receive a winmail.dat attachment inside a secure email, there is a misconfiguration on the sender's side, either in Microsoft Outlook or Exchange.

Solution at the Sender's Microsoft Outlook Level

There are a few different options to check on Microsoft Outlook to ensure emails are being sent via HTML and not Rich Text Format (RTF).

Check the Formatting of All Emails - Version 1

Check the formatting of all emails by following the steps below:

  1. Navigate to File Options.
  2. Select Mail.
  3. Ensure the Compose messages in this format option is set to HTML.

Check the Formatting of All Emails - Version 2

Check the formatting of a new email or the formatting of a reply to an email. You can check this by selecting Format Text from the top bar on a new email or reply and ensuring that HTML is selected.

Check the Formatting of All Emails - Version 3

Check the formatting settings on a per-user basis, as there may be different settings. To do this, follow the steps below:

  1. Select the People button at the bottom left-hand corner of Microsoft Outlook.
  2. Double-click the user's email address to which you are having problems sending. This action will open their contact card.
  3. Right-click their email address on this contact card and select Open Outlook Properties.
  4. On the new window that appears, ensure emails are not being sent in Rich Text Format.

Delete the Cache of the Recipient's Email Address

The cached version of the recipient's email address may cause issues. To delete the cached version of a recipient's email address, follow the steps below:

  1. On a new email, start typing the recipient's email address in the To field.
  2. The drop-down menu of cached email addresses will be displayed. Select the X icon after the recipient.
  3. Type the recipient's email address again manually. This action should resolve the issue.

Solution at the Sender's Server Level

Note:This solution will need to be passed on to the sender's IT Department.

When our gateway receives an email from Microsoft Exchange, it wraps everything up in a .switch file, and occasionally, a Winmail.dat attachment is included. Unfortunately, in certain instances, Microsoft Exchange may not be able to process the email correctly before passing it on to Gateway.

The attachment seems lost before we process the message for encryption. This issue could be a variety of reasons, such as:

  1. We encourage you to consider whether these senders are using RTF instead of the default HTML formatting. This action can be done on a per-recipient basis.
  2. Changing an attribute in the actual contact on the Global Address List may resolve the issue.

Microsoft Exchange 2007/2010

To change an attribute in Microsoft Exchange 2007/2010, follow the steps below:

  1. Run the Exchange System Manager program.
  2. In the left panel, navigate to Global Settings Internet Message Formats Standard.
  3. In the context menu, choose Properties and navigate to the Advanced tab.
  4. Set the Exchange rich-text format option to Never use.

Microsoft Exchange 2013

To change an attribute in Microsoft Exchange 2013, follow the steps below:

  1. Open Exchange Management Shell.

  2. To see your current settings, run the following command:

    Get-RemoteDomain | Where {$_.TNEFEnabled -ne $false}

  3. For each Remote domain, run the following command:

    Set-RemoteDomain -Identity DomainName -TNEFEnabled $false

articles.name: How to Prohibit Users from Disabling the Add-In
articles.title: How to Prohibit Users from Disabling the Add-In
articles.body:
A default deployment of the add-in allows users to disable the add-in manually in Microsoft Outlook or other Office applications.

Admins can override this setting by enabling the relevant group policy setting. This setting will prevent users from manually disabling the add-in.

To prevent users from disabling the Outlook add-in, open the Group Policy Editor and check that the Office Administrative Templates are installed. These can be located in User Configuration Administrative Templates Microsoft Outlook [YEAR] Miscellaneous.

If they are not installed, the administrative templates for Microsoft are available at the below URL:

  • Office 2016: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=49030

Complete the following steps below to ensure that users cannot disable an Office add-in:

  1. Ensure that the List of managed add-ins setting is set to Enabled.
  2. Select Show... in the List of managed add-ins.
  3. Write "Egress.Switch" and set the value to 1. This action will ensure the add-in cannot be disabled.

Alternatively, it's possible to deploy the registry key via GPO. The registry key type should be REG_SZ.

articles.name: Will Secure Email work via a proxy server?
articles.title: Will Secure Email work via a proxy server?
articles.body:
There are various ways your computer can be connected to the internet. We have tested the Protect Client in many different configurations, and there should be no issues with the following environments:

  • Directly connected to the internet
  • Behind a NAT firewall or router
  • Behind the Microsoft ISA server

If you are experiencing a connectivity problem and are unable to sign in to the Protect network, please contact your network admin. Issues are generally specific to your network environment and can be easily resolved.

articles.name: Egress COM Add-In - Microsoft Outlook Add-In Not Displayed to Users
articles.title: Egress COM Add-In - Microsoft Outlook Add-In Not Displayed to Users
articles.body:
Microsoft Outlook disables add-ins that take more than one second to load. In some rare circumstances, our Microsoft Outlook COM add-in may take over one second to load and could be disabled by Microsoft Outlook.

What Is the Fix for This Issue?

From Microsoft Office 2013 and onwards, Microsoft introduced the concept of resiliency keys. These are registry keys that prevent our Outlook add-in from being auto-disabled by Microsoft Outlook.

Note:Resiliency keys are applied on a per-user basis, so any new users on a machine will also need to have these keys enabled as per option 2.

Option 1: Download the Latest Add-In Version

Ensure that you have downloaded the latest Microsoft Outlook add-in.

All versions of our Outlook add-in, v23.03 and later, automatically add resiliency keys to the user’s registry during a fresh install and during upgrades from previous versions.

Option 2: Manually Update Registry Keys

If, for some reason, your organization is not able to upgrade to v23.03 or later, follow the steps below to add the registry keys to the user’s profile manually:

Name Value String Location
EgressEmailProtection 1 String [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\office\16.0\outlook\Resiliency\AddinList]
LoadBehavior 3 DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection]
EgressEmailProtection 1 DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\DoNotDisableAddinList]
EgressEmailProtection\dtype 0 DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]
EgressEmailProtection 967a844d DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]

If the COM add-in has been previously disabled for this user, then this information is stored in the registry and will prevent admins from re-enabling the Egress Outlook add-in. The following keys need to be deleted:

  • [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\DisabledItems]
  • [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\CrashingAddinList]

Option 3: Run a Registry key File

We have packaged options 1 and 2 into a registry file. This package can be downloaded here: https://workspace.egresscloud.com/quickshare/uNoM5PnJ. To run it, double-click on this file on a user’s machine. The logged-on user must run this file; otherwise, the registry keys will be applied in the wrong location.

articles.name: How to disable Egress automatic sign in
articles.title: How to disable Egress automatic sign in
articles.body:
There may be instances where you would like to stop the Egress Client from automatically signing you in. Follow the steps below to do this. 
NOTE: You may need to request these changes from your IT department depending on your permission settings. 
 

To turn off the automatic sign in feature:

  1. Open Regedit.
To do this: click the Start button. In the Start Menu, either in the Run box or the Search box, type "regedit" and press Enter.
  1. Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Egress\Switch and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Wow6432Node\Egress\Switch
  2. Right click in the white space on the right hand side of Regedit, underneath (Default) and create a DWORD, called DisableAutoSignIn with a value of 0 (zero) to disable auto sign in.
  3. You can change the value back to 1 if you wish to re-enable automatic sign in.

This key can also be configured at the user level instead of the machine level, by adding them to the respective folders above but by changing HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE to HKEY_CURRENT_USER.

articles.name: How to find your password for a secure email with an additional password or Multi Layer Authentication (MLA)
articles.title: How to find your password for a secure email with an additional password or Multi Layer Authentication (MLA)
articles.body:
Multi-Layer Authentication (MLA) can be configured to have a password set automatically for all users, or it could be created by the individual each time they send a secure email.

The steps below demonstrate how to set and locate your password for a secure email. These steps will allow you to recall the password should you forget it, or you can change it if required.

How to Send a Secure Email with Added MLA

To send a secure email with added MLA, follow the steps below:

  1. Create a new email in Microsoft Outlook.

  2. Select the classification that has MLA applied.

  3. Once your email is filled out and ready to send, click the Send button. This action will bring up the MLA prompt box and display the predetermined question that you can then set an "answer" which the recipient will need to enter upon opening your email.

How to Find the Answer to an Email You Have Sent

  1. Log in to your administration panel.
  2. On the left side of the screen, select Sent Packages.

  3. Use the date tabs to find the email you want to check and click the Package Label of that email.

  4. Once you have clicked on the package, the Details tab will display the password you have set in the Tag field.

    Remember to Save Changes if you make any amendments to your package details.

articles.name: Best Practice for Group Mailboxes
articles.title: Best Practice for Group Mailboxes
articles.body:
Setting up a Group Mailbox Account

Should a secure email need to be sent from a group mailbox, an account must be created for this email address. Group mailboxes are set up the same way as normal users, except for the admin, who should specify the password upon creation to ensure that this is documented in case group mailbox users attempt to reset the account.

Once the account has been activated, an admin should follow the steps below:

  1. Sign in to the Administration Panel and navigate to User Management.
  2. Select the group mailbox and navigate to the Authentication tab.
  3. Unselect the option Allow user to reset password via self-help.

Following these steps ensures the password reset can only be managed by admins or service desk users, which will avoid having the account reset by multiple users when forgotten.

Using a Group Mailbox

To send securely from a group mailbox, the user should sign in with the group mailbox credentials, and send the group email through Microsoft Outlook as normal.

Once sent, the user should then sign out and sign back in with their personal credentials.

Managing a Group Mailbox Packages

Should a secure email from a group mailbox need to be revoked because it was sent to the wrong person or an access request needs to be approved, the user can sign into the client or the Administration Panel with the mailbox credentials and navigate to Sent Packages to complete the necessary actions.

An admin can also have full visibility over these group mailbox packages by selecting the account from User Management and clicking the yellow package icon next to the account. The admin can then manage that specific user’s packages.

articles.name: Has my Egress Secure Email been read?
articles.title: Has my Egress Secure Email been read?
articles.body:
Any successful and failed attempts to access an Egress email are audited. 
These audit logs are never deleted and can be accessed via: 

  • The Sent Packages button within Outlook (you must have the Egress add-in enabled to use this feature)
  •  Within the Sent Packages area in your Egress Administration Panel 

 

Once you have accessed the audit log, click the appropriate package. The 'Package properties' will open and you can select the Audit Events tab to show any successful and failed attempts to access the package.

articles.name: How to Create a New Secure Email Using the Secure Message Portal
articles.title: How to Create a New Secure Email Using the Secure Message Portal
articles.body:
To create a secure email, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your administration panel.

  2. Select New Secure Email under Web Access from the menu on the left side of the screen.
  3. A new message window will open.

  4. Compose your message, and when you are done, click Send Secure or click Save Draft if you want to save it for later.

You have now sent a secure email. By default, a copy of the secure email will be sent to your email inbox for you to refer back to.

articles.name: Protect - Revoking Secure Email Access
articles.title: Protect - Revoking Secure Email Access
articles.body:
Protect allows you to revoke access to a secure email at any time, even after you've sent the secure email. You can do this in two ways:

Option One: Revoking Access in Microsoft Outlook

You can revoke a message in Microsoft Outlook by selecting the message and then clicking on Revoke Access, located in the top ribbon of the viewing pane.

Once access has been revoked, the recipient will see the following notification when they attempt to view the message.

Option Two: Revoking Access in the Administration Panel

To revoke access in the administration panel, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to the administration panel.

  2. Select Sent Packages on the left-hand side menu.

  3. Select the secure email in question. You can filter through these using the tabs as shown below:

  4. Open the Details tab for the email in question.
  5. Change the Status field from Active to Revoked.

  6. Click Save Changes at the bottom of the screen to apply your changes.

Once the status is changed to Revoked the email will no longer be visible to anyone. You can change the status back to Active at any time to re-allow recipient access.

articles.name: Enable Protect Client Logging
articles.title: Enable Protect Client Logging
articles.body:
If you have been asked to send the logs to our support team for analysis, please ensure you can replicate the issue at least once after logging has been enabled. This action will ensure that the issue you may be experiencing is recorded in these logs and allow the support team to see this in more detail.

Versions 23.9 and Later

From versions 23.9 and later, logging should be enabled by default.

To check this and locate the logs, please follow the steps below:

  1. In Microsoft Outlook, navigate to File and then Egress option on the bottom-left side of the options, as shown in the screenshot below.
  2. Once on the Settings page on the right side of the screen, click Open log location in Explorer, which will open a folder.

  3. From the folder, attach all of the logs found in this location unless the support team asks you to provide a specific log file.

Versions Below 23.9

Logging can be enabled in Microsoft Outlook or via the registry key.

Option One: Outlook

To enable logging in Microsoft Outlook, follow the steps below:

  1. In Microsoft Outlook, under the File menu, select Egress.

  2. On the right side of the page, ensure that the Enable Logging check box is selected.

  3. After logging is enabled and the issue has been replicated, navigate back to where the logging was enabled and select the Open log location in Explorer option.
Note:Please attach all of the logs found in this location unless asked by a member of the support teams ask you to provide a specific log file.

Option Two: Registry Key

To enable logging by registry key, follow the steps below:

  1. Open Regedit.
    1. Click the Start button.
    2. In the Start menu, either in the Run or Search box, type "regedit" and press Return or Enter.
  2. Navigate to: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Egress\Switch and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Wow6432Node\Egress\Switch
  3. Right-click in the white space on the right side of Regedit and create a DWORD called LoggingLevel, with a value of 4.

To retrieve the logs, navigate to: C:\Users\[USER]\AppData\Local\Temp\switch\logs

If using an RDS environment, please be aware that logging may instead be present in the following file location: C:\Users\[USER]\AppData\Local\switch\logs.

Note:Please attach all of the logs found in this location unless asked by a member of the support teams asks you to provide a specific log file.

articles.name: Install Protect Outlook Add-in for Windows PC
articles.title: Install Protect Outlook Add-in for Windows PC
articles.body:
Installing Protect for Windows PC will create an add-in within Microsoft Outlook, allowing your users to receive the benefits of the Prevent and/or Protect functionality that your organization has purchased.

The Outlook add-ins for Windows PC can be downloaded here. You can have the choice to deploy the COM add-in or the Web add-in. To decide which add-in meets your organization's requirements, see the Outlook Add-Ins: COM vs Web article.

Note:This article covers the installation of the COM add-in. If you choose to deploy the Web add-in, please refer to the Web Add-In-Deployment Guide.Once you have downloaded the add-in, you will need to run the installation file.
  1. Agree to the terms and conditions and then click Install.
  2. In the next window, click Next.
  3. A progress bar will be displayed while Protect is installing. Once finished, you will see a window that lets you know the installation is complete.

Protect has now been installed and will be visible within Outlook.

articles.name: Prevent - How to Disable the Gateway
articles.title: Prevent - How to Disable the Gateway
articles.body:
This article provides a comprehensive guide on disabling Prevent, including the necessary steps to modify Microsoft 365 settings, on-premise Microsoft Exchange configurations, and other secure email gateways. Whether you're transitioning to a different email security solution or need to disable Prevent temporarily, this step-by-step guide will walk you through the process, ensuring a smooth and secure transition for your organization's email communications.

You will first need to complete the following steps:

  • Disable any Egress mail flow rules within Microsoft 365 and any other secure email gateway.
  • Disable the Egress Transport Agent if used in combination with on-premise Microsoft Exchange.
  • Remove any Egress send and receive connectors in Microsoft 365 or on-premise Microsoft Exchange.
  • Remove any Egress connectors or accepted relays at any other secure email gateway.

If you wish to continue using the Microsoft Outlook add-in without the gateway, you should remove the following registry keys which will have been used to enable gateway mode:

  • [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Egress\Switch] "Forcegatewaymode" "Gatewayaddress" "MinimumSizeKB"
  • [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Egress\Switch] "Forcegatewaymode" "Gatewayaddress" "MinimumSizeKB"

If you do not wish to continue using our Outlook add-in, you should also remove this. At the end of your contract, any customized policies, including branding, will be reverted to the default configuration.

articles.name: Prevent - How to Prevent Users from Disabling the Add-In
articles.title: Prevent - How to Prevent Users from Disabling the Add-In
articles.body:
A default deployment of the add-in allows users to disable the add-in in Microsoft Outlook or other Microsoft Office applications manually. 

Admins can override this setting by enabling the relevant group policy setting. This setting will prevent users from manually disabling the add-in. 

To prevent users from disabling the Outlook add-in, follow the steps below:

  1. Open the Group Policy Editor and check that the Office Administrative Templates are installed. These can be located in User Configuration Administrative Templates Microsoft Outlook[YEAR] Miscellaneous.
  2. If they are not installed, the administrative templates for Microsoft are available at the below URLs:
    • Office 2016: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=49030
    • Office 2013: https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/download/details.aspx?Id=35554
  3. Ensure the "List of managed add-ins" setting is set to Enabled.
  4. Select Show... in the "List of managed add-ins".
  5. Enter "Egress.Switch" and set the value to 1. This action will ensure the add-in cannot be disabled.
  6. Alternatively, it's possible to deploy the registry key via Group Policy (GPO). The Registry Key type should be REG_SZ.

articles.name: Integrate Red Vector’s Fulcrum with Your KSAT Console
articles.title: Integrate Red Vector’s Fulcrum with Your KSAT Console
articles.body:
You can integrate Red Vector’s Fulcrum platform into your KSAT console. Fulcrum integrates cyber, human, and open-source intelligence to identify and mitigate insider threats proactively. Integrating Fulcrum with KSAT can help you identify possible workplace threats earlier by performing risk analysis. This integration also allows you to assign training campaigns to reduce workplace risks.

Connecting Fulcrum to Your KSAT Console

Before you set up Smart Groups in KSAT and create custom events in Fulcrum, you must create a User Event API key in KSAT’s Account Settings. Please see our User Event API documentation for more information.

Creating a Custom Event for KSAT

You must create a custom event in your Fulcrum platform to add users to a Smart Group. This event will be added to the Smart Group Criteria in KSAT. To create a custom event, please use our User Event API Documentation.

Note:The target_user attribute is needed for the API call. To set this custom event, you will need to use a user's email address registered in KnowBe4’s KSAT console. You can remove this event later within the User Timeline.

Setting Up Smart Groups in KSAT

You can set up Smart Groups in your KSAT console to assign users to groups automatically based on user events. Assigning users to Smart Groups allows you to assign training campaigns based on user events to specific users. Follow the steps below to create a Smart Group.

  1. In your KSAT console, navigate to the Users tab.
  2. Under Users, select Groups.
  3. On the right side of the page, click + Create New Group.
  4. Under Create New Group, give your Smart Group a name. You can customize the name of your Smart Group based on the workplace risk you wish to identify. In this example, the name is Workplace Violence.
  5. Select the Make This a Smart Group check box.
  6. Click Create Group.
  7. Select the Smart Group Criteria drop-down menu from the Smart Group page and click Custom Event.
  8. A Custom Event dialog menu should appear. Add the following configurations to the menu:  
    Condition Must
    Event Type event_type attribute from your created Custom Event, such as “Workplace Violence”
    Matcher Greater Than
    Count 0
    Timeframe Any
  9. Click Save.

Setting Up KSAT Training Campaigns with Fulcrum

You can set up Fulcrum to perform user risk analysis, which will allow you to assign KSAT training campaigns to specific users. Follow the steps below to perform risk analysis and set up KSAT training campaigns with Fulcrum.

Set Up KnowBe4 as a Fulcrum Send Action

First, you will need to set up KnowBe4 as a Fulcrum Send Action. Follow the steps below to complete this task.

  1. On Fulcrum’s app node, navigate to /rv/fulcrum/conf/fulcrum and open the file externalApps-config.json for editing. A sample entry is shown below:
  2. Add another entry in this file that provides Fulcrum with an external application option called “Assign Training.” The example below uses “Workplace Violence,” per the Smart Group created in the previous section.
  3. Save this file and then create the save directory on the app node to capture action messages: $ mkdir /rv/fulcrum/data/assign-training
  4. Once this is completed, restart Fulcrum services on the app node.

Setting Up Workflows in Fulcrum

Red Vector will provide a pre-configured workflow to run in Nifi to forward the data to KnowBe4.

The FetchEmailAndEventType processor needs to map the target_user attribute to your email attribute, as an email is how KSAT identifies a user.

The InvokeKnowBe4EventsEndpoint processor must be configured with your region's appropriate KnowBe4 API endpoint and a bearer token.

Assigning KSAT Training Campaigns Using Fulcrum

Once you have set up KnowBe4 as a Fulcrum Send Action and configured the above processors, the workflow can be activated, and Fulcrum is ready to assign training campaigns in KSAT. You can identify possible workplace risks in Fulcrum by reviewing risky behavior across your organization. Follow the steps below to assign KSAT training campaigns using Fulcrum.

  1. If you have identified a user of concern in your organization, you can navigate to the people details page to assess possible risky behavior. Here, you can view the user’s Risk Indicators.
  2. On the people details page, click the three-line icon on the right side of the page. Then, click Send Actions.
  3. Click the Send Actions button.
  4. In the External Application drop-down menu, select Assign Training.
  5. In the Action drop-down menu, select your previously created training type.
  6. Click the Send button to assign training.

articles.name: Prevent - The Shield Icon Has Disappeared from Microsoft Outlook
articles.title: Prevent - The Shield Icon Has Disappeared from Microsoft Outlook
articles.body:
You may occasionally get reports that the Prevent shield icon has disappeared from a user's Microsoft Outlook. There are multiple potential causes for this problem. This article will walk you through the most common issues behind the missing Prevent shield icon and how to resolve them.

Simplified Ribbon

The most common cause of the Prevent shield icon disappearing is the Simplified Ribbon view, which reduces the number of icons visible on the toolbar. This issue can occur if the user has either manually selected this option or if a Microsoft Outlook update has automatically switched to this view.

To restore the Prevent shield icon in this case:

  1. Open a new email window in Microsoft Outlook.
  2. Navigate to the far-right side of the toolbar and select the downward arrow icon.
  3. From the drop-down menu, select Classic Ribbon.

This option will restore the ribbon to its original, more detailed view, allowing the full array of icons, including the Prevent shield icon, to be displayed.

Multiple Outlook Add-Ins

If a user has multiple Microsoft Outlook add-ins, one of them may have taken precedence over the Prevent shield icon in the ribbon.

To resolve this issue, follow the steps below:

  1. In Microsoft Outlook, navigate to File Options Add-ins.
  2. Disable or reorder the add-ins to ensure the Prevent shield icon is given priority.
  3. Restart Microsoft Outlook to apply the changes.

These steps will ensure that the Prevent shield icon remains visible on the ribbon.

articles.name: Prevent - User Guide: COM Add-In
articles.title: Prevent - User Guide: COM Add-In
articles.body:
Prevent helps to avoid data breaches such as sending an email to the wrong recipient, attaching the wrong file to an email, and ensuring sensitive data is not shared with unauthorized recipients.

Note:The information contained in this guide is the default configuration of Prevent. Your experience may vary depending on your organization’s configuration choices.
Expand the sections below to learn more about the Prevent functionality.
  • When composing an email, you will see the Prevent shield icon in your Microsoft Outlook ribbon. As you add recipients to your email, the shield icon will respond to your choices. The color of the shield icon is representative of Prevent’s status:
    Shield  Description
    Prevent is not active yet, or your Microsoft Outlook is offline.
    Prevent is active and has not detected anything unusual. 
    Prevent has identified potential risks, and suggested actions are available in the side panel or upon pressing send. 
    Prevent has identified high risks, and suggested actions are available in the side panel or upon pressing send.

    To open the task pane containing more information and suggested changes, select the Prevent shield icon. 

    Clicking on the shield icon when composing your email will display a risk assessment of your recipients. When Prevent detects a risk, hover over the email address to understand why. Select the three-dot icon to select the suggested action. An example is shown in the screenshot below:

    Upon sending, you may also be prompted with guidance. An example is shown in the screenshot below:

    Review the information provided in the prompt, which will be tailored to the risk detected. In most cases, a Send Anyway option is presented that can be selected if you want to proceed. If you need to cancel and, for example, replace misaddressed recipients, select Cancel. See the Prevent - On-Send Prompt Triggers article to learn about all the different scenarios that can lead to receiving a prompt. 

  • The Prevent experience is different on mobile compared to Microsoft Outlook Add-In. You will receive feedback in an email when a potential risk is identified. This email will provide a risk assessment summary and give you a chance to approve and send the email or reject and discard the email, as seen in the screenshot below:

    Depending on the configuration set by your admins, if you do not action this email, your email will automatically be sent or rejected after a given time period.

articles.name: Prevent Change Log
articles.title: Prevent Change Log
articles.body:
Release Date Description
November 2025
  • November 18, 2025 - We’re excited to announce the release of our new navigation menu, enhanced login page, and updated KnowBe4 logo! For additional information, see our Login Page and Navigation Menu Overview article.
July 2025

We're excited to introduce an update to Prevent. The key details for this release are as follows:

  • A new Prevent Settings page
    • Prevent now has a settings page where you can configure your policies and maintain your internal domains.
  • The Prevent Deployment Center
    • We have released the Prevent deployment center, where you can efficiently deploy Prevent to your organization using a guided deployment wizard.

For full details, see the following articles:

  • Prevent - Understanding Prevent Settings
  • Prevent Quickstart Guide
Release Date Description
December 2024
  • December 2024 - We're excited to introduce a new on-send prompt to help avoid misdirected emails. Prevent now compares the recipient's email address and the salutation of the email. If a mismatch is detected, the user will be prompted to warn them that they may be sending an email to the wrong person.
  • The key details for this release are as follows:
    • This functionality is active for one-to-one emails sent to external recipients.
    • The salutation of an email is considered to be the first 50 characters of the email body.
    • These events will be displayed in the Prevent Analytics console under the Misdirected Email category.
    • This feature is enabled by default for all users.
    • No additional configuration is required.
October 2024
  • October 2024 - We're excited to announce an update to the Prevent dashboard, introducing a new data exfiltration widget. This enhancement is part of our ongoing commitment to improving product functionality and providing valuable insights to our users.
  • The key details for this release are as follows:
    • New data exfiltration widget on the Prevent dashboard displaying top-level statistics for potential data exfiltration events:
      • Total number of potential data exfiltration events
      • Events containing attachments
      • Events with detected data matches
    • Click through functionality to view relevant events in the event finder

    • This update will be automatically applied to your Prevent platform, requiring no action from administrators.
June 2024
  • June 2024 - As part of our continuous product improvement plan, Prevent Analytics has been refreshed with improved functionality and new features. The following changes will be automatically applied to your Prevent platform, and no further action from administrators is required:
    • The Search Emails page has been refreshed, and additional filters have been added
    • Wildcards can be used to aid your search
    • Your search results will now be displayed in a more context-rich table
    • When selecting an event from the search results, the event page will now include:
      • High-level information regarding prompts displayed to end-users
      • A log of recipients, including the recipients who Prevent flagged, the recipients changed by the end-user, and the final recipients of the sent email
      • Details of data in the email that matched Prevent policies

articles.name: Prevent - Technical Overview
articles.title: Prevent - Technical Overview
articles.body:
Prevent helps users avoid errors and accidental mistakes when sharing data and Personally Identifiable Information (PII) by email. By combining historical email behavior trends, domain hygiene analysis, and Data Loss Prevention (DLP) rules, Prevent advises end users on the risk level of an email.

This guide provides a comprehensive overview of the Prevent system and deployment.

Components

Prevent is formed of the following components:

  • API
    • Learns user behavior to provide accurate opinions and prompts
    • Responsible for metadata ingestion and storage
  • Policy Engine
    • Determines what to do with Prevent’s opinion of an email, such as when to prompt users in accordance with your policy
  • Client Add-In
    • Enforces the policy and prompts users when required
  • Prevent Gateway
    • For emails that are not processed by the COM or web add-in

Architecture

  1. Prevent Microsoft Outlook add-in triggers single sign-on (SSO) authentication when Microsoft Outlook starts up.
  2. Prevent Microsoft Outlook add-in makes a call to the Prevent policy server to retrieve security policies. These security policies control the behavior of the add-in, such as what scenario to show a prompt to the user.
  3. Analysis of email content and recipients occurs during composition and on sending the email. Prompts in line with Prevent security policies are delivered where necessary.
  4. Email sent to the recipient via the normal route, such as Microsoft Exchange and then SEG (optional).
  5. User actions are ingested to allow Prevent to learn and constantly provide accurate advice to users. This data is also ingested into the Prevent Analytics platform for reporting purposes.

Ingestion

For Prevent to provide the most value, it requires a baseline dataset and an understanding of email relationships. This data is acquired through ingestion. There are two ingestion methods that can be used:

  • Graph API Ingestion
    • Ingests 12 months of metadata if available.
    • Only available for organizations using Microsoft Exchange Online.
    • Graph API ingestion is a mandatory requirement if using the web add-in.
    • Graph API ingestion is a mandatory requirement for shared mailbox support. This feature ensures users receive real-time Prevent advice when sending from a shared mailbox or on behalf of another user.
  • Windows Outlook COM Add-In Ingestion
    • Ingests 12 months of metadata, if available, via the Microsoft Outlook add-in.

Data Storage

The data stored by Prevent includes:

  • Sender
  • From
  • Sender Display Name
  • From Display Name
  • Recipients – display name and email
  • SentBy Address
  • Mailbox Address
  • Sent Date
  • Parent Thread Index
  • Message References
  • Thread Index
  • Exchange Message Class
  • Message ID
  • InReplyTo Message ID
  • Hashed identifiers *
  • Subject line*
  • Attachment names*

*This data is optional and ingested to display additional information in the Prevent Security Center.

All data is stored for 18 months. All activity between the application and its underlying data sources occurs over a secure connection using TLS 1.2.

Data Segregation

Customer data is isolated by assigning each organization an ID. Authentication and database queries to Prevent are made at an organizational level, ensuring that data cannot be accessed between organizations.

Data Retention

The retention period for Prevent Analytics is 18 months rolling and for up to 30 calendar days thereafter. This data is required to improve the accuracy of the Prevent services and provide trend and risk analysis for reporting. For more information, see our Data Retention Policy Schedule.

Network Configuration

Communication to the Prevent cloud is via HTTPS. If SSL inspection or decryption is being used, a customer may be required to add proxy exceptions to bypass this for URLs given below to avoid interference.

United Kingdom

  • switch.egress.com
  • uk.intelligence.egress.com
  • uk.office.egress.com
  • uk.kes.knowbe4.com

Europe

  • eu1.esi.egress.com
  • eu.intelligence.egress.com
  • eu.office.egress.com
  • eu.kes.knowbe4.com

North America

  • us1.esi.egress.com
  • us.intelligence.egress.com
  • us.office.egress.com
  • us.kes.knowbe4.com

Asia-Pacific

  • au.esi.egress.com
  • au.intelligence.egress.com
  • au.office.egress.com
  • au.kes.knowbe4.com

Graph API Ingestion Configuration

Graph API ingestion requires an app registration within your Entra ID tenant. This configuration can be done manually within the Entra ID admin platform or using Powershell. Global Administrator credentials are required.

To set this up, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Entra ID portal.
  2. Navigate to App registrations New registration.
  3. Populate the settings as shown below:
    Name Prevent
    Who can use this application or access this API? Accounts in this organizational directory only (Single Tenant)
  4. Click Register.
  5. Navigate to Authentication Add a platform Mobile and desktop applications.

  6. Select the URL ending with "/nativeclient" and click Configure.

  7. Add a new redirect URL with the value of urn:ietf:wg:oauth:2.0:oob

  8. Under Advanced Settings, enable Allow public client flows by selecting Yes.

  9. Click Save.
  10. Navigate to API Permissions Add a permission.
  11. Add the permissions below:
    1. Microsoft Graph Application Permissions User User.Read.All
    2. Microsoft Graph Application Permissions Group Group.Read.All
    3. Microsoft Graph Application Permissions Mail Mail.Read
  12. Click Add Permissions.

  13. Click Grant admin consent for your organization. Click Yes to any prompts asking you to override any existing permissions.

  14. Navigate to Certificates and Secrets. Add a new client secret with an expiry of 24 months. Copy the value of the secret immediately after creation. Your Prevent engineer will need this value.

  15. Navigate to the Overview page and note the Application (client) ID and Directory (tenant) ID. Your Prevent engineer will need these values.
  16. Pass the following information to your Prevent engineer:
    1. Application (client) ID.
    2. Directory (tenant) ID.
    3. Client secret value and date of expiry.

Gateway

Prevent has developed the Prevent Gateway to ensure that Prevent caters to non-outlook mail flow from sources, such as mobile devices or back-end systems.

Prevent Deployment Manager

The implementation of Prevent for mobile is achieved via a Deployment Manager, which will be run from the Prevent engineer’s machine. Full details on this Deployment Manager can be found within the following subsections, but it will require a Global Administrator from your tenant to authorize the implementation via Device Code authentication.

Authentication Requirements

Deployment Manager is a Windows application that is run by a KnowBe4 Engineer to enable remote and easy installation of Prevent for mobile. Using Microsoft OAuth Device authentication, the Deployment Manager authenticates with a client’s Microsoft 365 environment remotely. The Deployment Manager must be run on a KnowBe4 employee’s computer, connected to a KnowBe4 VPN, without the client needing to physically enter their username and password onto the KnowBe4 engineer’s device. It will require authorization from a Global Administrator within your tenant. A “token” is received from Microsoft Graph after login, which lasts between 60 and 90 minutes, and is discarded as soon as the page containing the auth flow is closed.

Conditional Access

The Prevent Deployment Manager will be run from the KnowBe4 engineer’s machine connected to a VPN from the UK or America. If you have Conditional Access policies applied to the Global Administrator who authorizes the scripts, you may need to make an exception to the Conditional Access Policy during the installation. The exception can be removed afterward.

General Flow

Emails sent from outside of the Prevent Microsoft Outlook Add-in are sent to a moderation mailbox in the Prevent Gateway and are scanned for any risks and processed accordingly. If a risk is detected, such as a misdirected email, the sender will receive a bounce-back verification email with the option to either approve and send or reject and discard the email. The flow of this feature is shown in the screenshot and list below:

  1. A mobile user sends an email.
  2. The email is redirected to the Prevent Gateway via SMTP for analysis.
  3. Prevent Gateway analyses the email for any risks. If no risks are detected, the email is automatically approved and released.
  4. If a risk is detected, the Prevent Gateway will send a verification email to the sender on behalf of the shared mailbox. The sender can review the verification email and either approve or reject the send of the email. Approved messages are returned to the Prevent Gateway queue for additional SMTP processing, with encryption or decryption if required, and then returned to Microsoft 365 for final delivery. Rejected messages are deleted with a notification message to the sender or released with a MIME header that Microsoft 365 rules can act upon if needed).
  5. Approved messages are returned to Microsoft 365 for delivery to the recipient.
  6. If a user takes no action, by default, emails are auto-approved after two hours.

Gateway Configuration

The Prevent Deployment Manager is used to configure the components required for the Prevent Gateway, reducing the risk of human error and the time required for the implementation. Below are the components implemented by the Deployment Manager:

  • Accepted Domain
    • Configuring an accepted domain allows us to route emails to the Prevent Gateway for processing. We do not configure an MX record, but we do use the MX record value.
  • Connectors
    • Allows emails to be transmitted between Microsoft 365 and Prevent over TLS 1.2, using the MS recommendation of CA-issued certificate-based authentication.
  • Microsoft 365 Group
    • The transport rules created, as shown below, are scoped to apply to a Microsoft 365 group. Prevent users will need to be manually added to the group.
  • Shared Mailbox
    • When a risk is detected, the Prevent Gateway will send a verification email to the sender to approve or reject whether or not the mail will be sent. This verification email is sent on behalf of the shared mailbox.
  • Transport Rules
    • There are two rules required. The first rule will determine what emails will be redirected to the Prevent Gateway. The second rule will determine if any emails are being sent to the shared mailbox, typically approve or reject responses, and redirect them to the Prevent Gateway.

If deployment using the deployment manager is not possible, the manual steps detailed in this section should be followed.

Prerequisites

The prerequisites needed for configuring the gateway are listed below:

  • Graph API ingestion configured
  • Microsoft 365
  • Microsoft 365 Global Administrator access

Accepted Domain

To configure an accepted domain, follow the steps below:

  1. In the Microsoft 365 admin portal, navigate to Setup.
  2. Under Get your custom domain set up, select View Manage Add domain.
  3. Configure the new domain using your Prevent Gateway domain address, which will be provided by your KnowBe4 Engineer.

Connectors

Send Connector

To configure a send connector, follow the steps below:

  1. In the M365 admin portal, navigate to Mail Flow Connectors.
  2. Click + Add a Connector.
  3. Set the mail flow scenario to be from Microsoft 365 to Partner Organization.
  4. Click Next.
  5. Enter a name for the connector.
  6. Click Next.
  7. Select the option to only use the connector where there is a transport rule associated with it.
  8. Click Next.
  9. Select Route email through these smart hosts.
  10. Add the Prevent hostname, which will be provided by your KnowBe4 Engineer.
  11. Click Next.
  12. Select Always use Transport Layer Security (TLS) to secure the connection.
  13. Tick Add the subject name and enter your Prevent hostname.
  14. Click Next.

Receive Connector

To configure a receive connector, follow the steps below:

  1. In the Microsoft 365 admin portal, navigate to Mail Flow Connectors.
  2. Click + Add a connector.
  3. Set the mail flow scenario to be from Your Organization to Microsoft 365.
  4. Click Next.
  5. Enter a name for the connector.
  6. Click Next.
  7. Enter the Prevent Gateway hostname to allow Microsoft 365 to identify the source of incoming mail.

Microsoft 365 Group

To configure a Microsoft 365 group, follow the steps below:

  1. In the Microsoft 365 admin portal, navigate to Active Teams and Groups.
  2. Select Add a Microsoft 365 group.
  3. Enter a name for the group, such as "Prevent Moderation".
  4. Click Next.
  5. Assign an owner of the group.
  6. Click Next.
  7. Add relevant members to the group.
  8. Click Next.
  9. Enter a group email address, such as "Prevent_Users@customer.com".
  10. Use the Privacy drop-down menu to select Private.
  11. Untick Create a team for this group.
  12. Click Next.
  13. Review and create the group.

Once created, add the desired Prevent users to the group.

Shared Mailbox

Create the shared mailbox in the Microsoft 365 admin portal by following the steps below:

  1. Navigate to Teams & Groups Shared mailboxes.
  2. Click + Add a shared mailbox.
  3. The address of the mailbox should be Egress_Moderator@customer.com
  4. Click Save Changes.

Prevent will send verification emails on behalf of this shared mailbox. These emails will originate from an internal address but from an external Prevent IP address and will therefore, be rejected due to SPF misalignment. To prevent these rejections, the Gateway hostname should be allowed to spoof the mailbox address within your Microsoft Security Portal:

  1. Navigate to Policies and Rules Threat Policies Tenant Allow/Block Lists Spoofed senders.
  2. Add a new domain pair including the moderator mailbox address and your Prevent Gateway regional address, which can be provided by your KnowBe4 Engineer.

Transport Rules

Prevent Moderation

To configure Prevent moderation, follow the steps below:

  1. In the Microsoft 365 admin portal, navigate to Mail Flow Rules + Create a new rule.

  2. Configure the rule with the following settings:

    Apply this rule if the Header

    X-MS-Exchange-Organization-AuthMechanism

    Matches

    ^0?4

    And is received from

    Member of group Egress_Prevent_Users@customer.com.

    Do the following

    Route the message using the following Connector:

    Exchange Online to Egress

    And Set the message header

    X-Egress-Moderation with the value Required

    Except if

    Message type is Calendaring

    Or

    Message Header X-Switch-Processed contains:

    [GATEWAY ID] this will be provided by you Prevent Engineer

    Or

    Message Header X-$Switch matches the following patterns:

    ^((?!TPSECONDARY).){1,1000}$

Forward Replies to Prevent SMTP Moderation

To forward replies to Prevent SMTP moderation, follow the steps below:

  1. In the Microsoft 365 admin portal, navigate to Mail Flow Rules + Create a new rule.

  2. Configure the rule with the following settings:

    Apply this rule if Received from

    Inside the Organization

    And is sent to recipient Egress_Prevent_Users@customer.com.

    Do the following

    Route the message using the connector

    Exchange Online to Egress

    And set the Message Header

    X-Egress-Moderation with the value required

    Except if the header

    [GATEWAY ID] this will be provided by your Prevent Engineer

articles.name: Prevent Resource Hub
articles.title: Prevent Resource Hub
articles.body:
Welcome to the Prevent Resource Hub. We hope to make your onboarding experience as smooth as possible by providing you with the necessary resources for both admins and end-users.

  • For Admins: We have guides to assist with the deployment process of Prevent.
  • For End Users: We have bite-sized videos and user guides to share with end-users to help them understand and maximize the functionalities of Prevent.
Tip:To view a Prevent product demo, see our KnowBe4 Product Demos article.

articles.name: Prevent - Nudges
articles.title: Prevent - Nudges
articles.body:
The following scenarios are the typical triggers that can cause Prevent to nudge you with advice when you send an email.

Trigger Explanation
Misdirected Email

This nudge is triggered when an email is sent to multiple recipients, but one or more recipients are not usually included in the type of communication being sent.
Misspelled Recipient

This nudge is triggered when a recipient's email address appears to be a misspelled version of a known contact that you have previously communicated with.
Salutation Mismatch

This nudge is triggered when the person greeted in the email body differs from the recipient's email address.
Large Recipient List

This nudge is triggered when there are a large number of recipients in the To or CC fields.
Data Exfiltration

This nudge is triggered when an email is sent to a personal or webmail address.
New Recipient

This nudge is triggered when an email is sent to a new and external email address.
External Domains

This nudge is triggered when an email is sent to too many external domains.
Impersonation

This nudge is triggered when you reply to an email received from an email address that impersonates a known contact.
Newly-registered Domain

This nudge is triggered when an email is sent to a domain that was registered less than 50 days ago.
Blocklist

This nudge is triggered when an email is sent to a domain with a malicious reputation.

articles.name: Prevent - Default Policies
articles.title: Prevent - Default Policies
articles.body:
This article outlines the best practices recommended for your Prevent policy configuration. These recommendations are derived from extensive research and implementation across various industries. By following these guidelines, organizations can significantly enhance their email security posture and mitigate potential risks.

Default Policies

The table below outlines the recommended default policy settings for Prevent:

Policy Risk Level Action
Misdirected Email  Medium Monitor & Nudge
Misspelled Recipient  Medium Monitor & Nudge
Salutation Mismatch Medium Monitor & Nudge
Large Recipient List Medium Monitor & Nudge
Data Exfiltration Medium Monitor
New Recipient Low Monitor
External Domains Medium Monitor
Impersonation Medium Monitor & Nudge
Newly-registered Domain  Medium Monitor & Nudge
Blocklist High Block
